item.label: Cerebral lobes
item.name: Cerebral lobes - arrows
item.description: Each cerebral hemisphere consists of lobes:  frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal.  In some instances a limbic lobe is designated-- consisting of a portion of the medial aspect of the other lobes.

item.label: Frontal
item.name: Frontal - arrows
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Parietal
item.name: _ADDParietal
item.description: The parietal lobe is the most centrally located lobe of the cerebral hemisphere, bounded by the frontal, occipital and temporal lobes. The parietal lobe is noted for functionally important areas: the post-central gyrus is primary somatosensory cortex, the inferior parietal lobule is important for language comprehension and areas of association cortex are involved with complex aspects of spatial orientation and perception.

item.label: Occipital
item.name: Occipital - arrows
item.description: The occipital lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres. It is clinically important because it includes the primary and association visual cortex.

item.label: Temporal
item.name: Temporal - arrows
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Cerebral gyri, Insula
item.name: Cerebral gyri Insula
item.description: The insula is an area of cerebral cortex (AKA insular cortex or Island of Reil) that is concealed by the opercula of the frontal, parietal and temporal gyri. It was originally the lateral surface of the telencephalon but was overgrown during development by the other cerebral lobes. It generally consists of three short gyri located anteriorly and two long gyri located posteriorly.

item.label: Cerebral fissure, Longitudinal
item.name: Cerebral fissure Longitudinal
item.description: The longitudinal cerebral fissure is AKA the median longitudinal fissure. it is a deep midline fissure located between the two cerebral hemispheres.  The cerebral falx (a dural reflection) extends into this fissure.

item.label: Septum pellucidum
item.name: Septum pellucidum
item.description: The septum pellucidum is a thin, almost transparent paired membrane that separates the two lateral ventricles. It is stretched out between the area of the septal nuclei and fornix inferiorly and the inferior surface of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Commissure, Corpus callosum
item.name: Commissure Corpus callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu is the sharp bend in the corpus callosum at it most anterior or rostral aspect.  The commissural fibers within the genu interconnect the frontal lobes.

item.label: Splenium
item.name: Splenium
item.description: The splenium is the thick and rounded posterior aspect of the corpus callosum.  These commissural axons interconnect the occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Crus
item.name: Crus
item.description: The crus is that portion of the fornix between the fimbria and body of the fornix. It curves superiorly to just beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body
item.description: The body of the fornix is the arched portion of the fornix that continues rostrally as the crus of each side unites beneath the septum pellucidum.

item.label: Internal capsule
item.name: Internal capsule
item.description: The internal capsule is a thick fiber bundle that is the primary route of communication between the cerebral cortex and other CNS structures. It includes the thalamocortical, corticothalamic, corticospinal, corticobulbar, etc. tracts. It consists of an anterior limb, genu and posterior limb that form a "V" shape as seen in mid-level horizontal or axial sections.   The lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus) is located laterally inside the "V" and the caudate nucleus and thalamus are located medially.

item.label: Anterior limb
item.name: Anterior limb
item.description: The anterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lenticular nucleus laterally and the head of the caudate nucleus medially. It includes thalamocortical fibers from the dorsomedial and anterior thalamic nuclei to the prefrontal and cingulate areas of cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu_1
item.description: The genu of the internal capsule is located where the anterior and posterior limbs meet. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA) and ventral lateral (VL) thalamic nuclei with the motor/premotor cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Posterior limb
item.name: Posterior limb
item.description: The posterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lentiform nucleus laterally and the thalamus medially. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA), ventral lateral (VL), ventral posterior nuclei (VPL/VPM) of thalamus with the motor, somatosensory and other areas of parietal cerebral cortex as well as corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers. A portion of the posterior limb passes beneath the lentiform nucleus (sublenticular); it includes the auditory radiation from the medial geniculate nucleus of thalamus to the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex and a portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to the occipital cerebral cortex. A portion of the posterior limb passes posterior to the lentiform nucleus (retrolenticular); it includes a major portion of the optic radiation from the lateral geniculate nucleus to occipital cerebral cortex plus connections between the thalamus (pulvinar and lateral posterior nuclei) and the parietal-occipital-temporal association cortex.

item.label: Corpus striatum
item.name: Corpus striatum
item.description: The corpus striatum includes the caudate nuclei, putamen and globus pallidus.  These nuclei are often referred to as the basal ganglia.   Note that the term "striatum" includes only the caudate nuclei plus the putamen.

item.label: Caudate nuclei, Head
item.name: Caudate nuclei, head
item.description: The head of the caudate nucleus is the largest portion of the caudate.  It bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is located medial to the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Lentiform nuclei, Putamen
item.name: Lentiform nuclei Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Stria & Vena terminalis
item.name: Stria_vena terminalis
item.description: The stria terminalis and vena terminalis run together through the lateral ventricle in the groove between the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.  The stria terminalis is a small fiber bundle that is part of the limbic system.  It originates in the amygdala and terminates in the septal area and hypothalamus. The vena terminalis is AKA the terminal vein and is part of the system of deep cerebral veins that drain the interior of the cerebrum.

item.label: Diencephalon, Thalamus
item.name: Diencephalon Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Arteries, branches of
item.name: Arteries, branches of
item.description: The arterial supply to the brain is via the paired internal carotid and vertebral arteries. The terminal branches of the internal carotid arteries are the paired anterior and middle cerebral arteries which supply supratentorial structures.  The two vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity via the foramen magnum; they join one another at the junction of the medulla with the pons to form the basilar artery.  Together the vertebral-basilar system of arteries supplies the structures of the posterior fossa as well as those supratentorial structures supplied by its terminal branches -- the posterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Anterior cerebral
item.name: Anterior cerebral
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Middle cerebral
item.name: Middle cerebral
item.description: The middle cerebral artery is the most posterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it travels through the lateral sulcus to supply the insula, the lateral aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes and the anterior tip of the temporal lobe. Since the middle cerebral artery supplies the pre- and post-central gyri which are responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso.

item.label: Cerebral veins, Superficial
item.name: Cerebral veins Superficial
item.description: Cerebral veins are described as superficial or deep, depending on whether they drain the superficial or deep aspects of the brain.  In general, the superficial veins lie on the surface of the cerebral hemispheres, where most empty into the superior sagittal sinus.

item.label: Dural reflection, Falx cerebri
item.name: Dural reflection Falx cerebri
item.description: The cerebral falx is AKA the falx cerebri.  Sickle-shaped dural reflection of the meningeal layer of the dura between the two cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Dural venous sinus, Superior sagittal
item.name: Dural venous sinus Superior sagittal
item.description: The superior sagittal sinus of the dural venous sinus system is located in the superior midline of the cerebral dura and thus, in the superior, attached edge of the cerebral falx. It receives venous blood from cerebral, diploic and emissary veins and joins the remainder of the sinus system at the confluence in the sinuses near the internal occipital protuberance.

item.label: Ventricular system, Lateral ventricles
item.name: Ventricular system Lateral ventricles
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Anterior horn
item.name: Anterior horn
item.description: The anterior horn of the lateral ventricle is AKA the frontal horn. This region of the lateral ventricle extends into the frontal lobe.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body_1
item.description: The body of the lateral ventricle is located between the anterior horn, rostrally, and the atrium or trigone, caudally.

item.label: Trigone
item.name: Trigone
item.description: The artrium or trigone of the lateral ventricle is where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.  It is located near the splenium of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
